citation.article-title: New genus of the Actinomycetales: Streptoalloteichus hindustanus gen. nov., nom. rev.; sp. nov., nom rev.

p.s: Description of Streptoalloteichus hindustanus sp. nov.
Streptoalloteichus hindustanus (hin'du.stan'us. L. adj. of Hindustan, northwest district of India)
(i) Aerial mycelium.
Aerial mycelium is well-developed and branched, averaging 0.5 μm in diameter.
Chains of spores are formed only at the tips of the aerial mycelium, either as long, open-coiled (10 to 50 spores in a chain), or short hooked branching spore chains.
Both types may be found in the same culture.
The arthrospores in the long chains are oval or cylindrical (0.5 to 2.0 μm in diameter), and the conidiospores in the short chains are mostly barrel shaped.
Both types of spores have a smooth surface.
A sclerotium may also be formed on the aerial mycelium.
(ii) Substrate mycelium.
The substrate mycelium does not fragment, and occasionally coalesces into a thick rope.
Single oval or spherical sporangium-like vesicles enveloping one spore, or a single row of two to four spores, are capriciously formed among the vegetative hyphae.
The sporangia measure 1.5 to 4.5 by 2.7 to 7.0 μm, and the sporangiospores are 0.9 to 1.5 by 1.2 to 4.0 μm, oval or rod shaped with a single polar flagellum.
Globose dense bodies, 3 to 20 μm in diameter, consisting of coalesced vegetative hyphae, are observed on the agar surface.
(iii) Chemotaxonomic analysis.
Purified cell walls of S. hindustanus contain meso-diaminopimelic acid, alanine and glutamic acid, as the wall peptidoglycan and lack any characteristic sugars.
The whole cell sugar pattern is a variant of type C (D-galactose, D-mannose, and L-rhamnose).
The phospholipids present are phosphatidylethanolamine and phosphatidylinositol, and hence a type PI1 pattern.
Mass spectra show that the major menaquinones are MK9(H6) and MK10(H6) in roughly equal amounts.
(iv) Appearance on various media.
All agar slants were incubated at 28°C and observed after 21 days.
The color names were from the ISCC-NBC Centroid color charts (5).
The growth is good on yeast extract-malt extract agar, inorganic salts-starch agar and tyrosine agar.

On these agar media, a thick mass of white aerial mycelia are produced turning to pale yellow or pale pinkish yellow after sporulation, and the substrate mycelia are off-white to light yellowish brown.
No diffusible pigment is produced.
On peptone-yeast extract-iron agar, the growth and aerial mycelium formation is scant, and a brownish weakly diffusible pigment is produced in the substrate mycelium.
(v) Physiological characteristics.
The temperature range for growth is 20 to 54°C.
No growth occurs at 56°C.
Melanin is not produced on peptone-yeast extract-iron agar and tyrosine agar, and the tyrosinase reaction is negative.
Gelatin is liquefied, starch is hydrolyzed, and nitrate is reduced to nitrite.
No growth occurs on media supplemented with more than 7% NaCl.

D-Fructose, D-galactose, D-glucose, D-mannose, maltose, and salicin are utilized, but L-arabinose, D-xylose, L-rhamnose, raffinose, inositol, D-mannitol, D-sorbitol, and inulin are not utilized for growth.
The utilization of sucrose and lactose is questionable.
